analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, an approximation-free funnel feedback controller is proposed for a class of nonlinear servomechanisms to achieve prescribed tracking error performance. An improved funnel function is proposed to guarantee the transient and asymptotic behavior of the tracking error within a given funnel boundary. The proposed funnel function removes the imposed assumption used in conventional funnel controls (e.g., systems with relative degree one or two) and avoids the potential singularity problem in prescribed performance controls. Moreover, an extended state observer (ESO) is used to address the effect of unknown dynamics in the control system (e.g., friction and disturbances), where the ESO parameters can be easily designed based on the control system bandwidth. The stability of the proposed control system with ESO and funnel function is analyzed via the Lyapunov theory. Comparative simulations and experimental results are conducted based on a practical turntable servomechanisms to validate the efficacy of the proposed method.

Note to Practitioners-This paper solves the precision motion control problem for servomechanisms subject to nonlinear friction, model uncertainties, and external disturbances, which are difficult to be modeled in practical applications. We will present an alternative control method to achieve guaranteed transient and steady-state error convergence performance. Moreover, we consider all lumped uncertainties as an augmented unknown system state, and then address their effect by using an extended state observer (ESO). The parameters of ESO are designed based on the control system bandwidth only. Practical experimental results with a turntable servo system reveal that the proposed controller is more effective than proportional-integral-derivative controller and a typical adaptive controller in terms of control performance. The simpler implementation and the reduced computational cost are also profitable in practice. Thus, this paper suggests a method for practitioners interested in developing motion controller for servomechanisms. Potential applications include aerospace, robotic systems, electrical vehicles, and marine systems.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: P ERMANENT-MAGNET synchronous motors (PMSMs) have been widely used in many industry applications due to their compact structure, high power density, high torque to inertia ratio and efficiency, etc. [1]- [3]. It is well known that linear control methods, e.g., proportional-integralderivative (PID) controls have been applied for the PMSM [4]. However, these linear control algorithms usually cannot ensure satisfactory dynamic performance in the entire operation range, because the PMSM servo systems may have nonlinear elements (e.g., friction), model uncertainties, and external disturbances. Thus, nonlinear control techniques have been further investigated to control the PMSM. In particular, with the development of modern control theory, various advanced nonlinear control techniques have been proposed for the PMSM, such as backstepping control [5]- [7], robust control [8], adaptive control [9]- [11], input-output linearization control [12], and sliding-mode control [13]. Moreover, artificial intelligent techniques have also been employed for the PMSM, e.g., neural network (NN) [14], [15], fuzzy logic system (FLS) [16]. Although the adaptive NN [14] or FLS [17] control methods can compensate for the effect of nonlinearities and modeling uncertainties, the induced approximation error and the increased computational cost may be problematic, and only semiglobal stability can be proved.

Moreover, the unmeasured external disturbances may also be unavoidable in practical application of PMSM systems, which can reduce control performance. To address these disturbances, one solution is to use a disturbance observer (DOB) to estimate the unknown disturbances. In 1987, a DOB-based control method was first proposed by Ohnishi [18]. Over the past years, the DOB-based control methods have been used in some practical industry applications, such as servo systems [19], [20], robotic systems [21], inverted-pendulum systems, and so on. In these case studies, different types of DOBs have been proposed, including fuzzy DOB [22], NN DOB [23], and linear DOB [19], [24]. Recently, a novel DOB called extended state observer (ESO) was developed by Han [25]. The merit of ESO is that the external disturbances and the unknown system dynamics are all lumped and then considered as a new state variable, and then, an ESO is designed to estimate the unknown dynamics and the system states. Following this idea, a robust control method with ESO that is named active disturbance rejection control was developed [26]- [30]. In [2], an adaptive speed control was proposed for PMSM with varying load inertia, where an ESO is utilized to estimate the system states and unknown disturbances simultaneously. Although these controllers with ESO can handle the unknown dynamics, it is noted that the transient control performance (e.g., overshoot, convergence rate, and steady-state error) of these aforementioned control schemes cannot be prescribed.

Recently, a new prescribed performance control (PPC) [31], [32] approach was proposed to guarantee the convergence of output error to a predefined arbitrarily small region. The key idea of the PPC is that the tracking error of the original system is transformed into a new coordinate by using a prescribed performance function. Then, this transformed error is employed in the control design, so that the tracking error of the original system can be retained within a prescribed region when the transformed system is stable. Several applications and improvements of this PPC technique have also been reported in [33]- [39]. However, it was found that there may be a potential singularity problem in the PPC methods, which may cause the violation of the prescribed performance constraints and even the instability of the control system in the worst case [40]. On the other hand, funnel control proposed in [41] and [42] is also able to guarantee a prescribed transient behavior and asymptotic tracking. The concept of funnel control as a proportional control leads to simplicity in the practical implementation. Moreover, for specific plants, the measurement noise and parameter uncertainties can be addressed without precise identification procedure. Thus, funnel control can be potentially suitable for both theoretical studies and practical application. Nevertheless, it is found that funnel control was only used for tracking control for mechanical systems with coupling elasticity [43] and robotic systems [44].

Motivated by the earlier observations, we proposed an improved funnel controller with ESO for nonlinear servomechanisms. An ESO, whose parameter is adjusted based on the bandwidth of the studied control system, is used to estimate the unknown lumped dynamics (including frictions, parameter uncertainties, and external disturbance), and to reduce their effect on the servomechanisms. The estimated dynamics are then incorporated into a funnel control synthesis, such that the prescribed transient and asymptotic tracking performance can be guaranteed. Inspired by [41]- [43], an improved funnel variable is proposed by relaxing the specific relative degree or a class of S condition on the studied systems. Then, this funnel control can guarantee the prescribed transient and steady-state boundaries. On the contrary to PPC, the complex transform function and thus the potential singularity problem are all avoided. Thus, the proposed method is suitable for more generic systems. The essential difference to the conventional funnel control is that the estimate of the lumped unknown dynamics is used in the controller such that the caused performance degradation can be addressed. Comparative simulations and experiments based on a turntable servo system are provided to validate the efficacy of the proposed method. The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows.

1) An improved funnel function, which can relax the imposed condition on conventional funnel control methods (e.g., systems with relative degree one or two [41], [42]), is proposed to extend the application of funnel control schemes. Moreover, the potential singularity problem in the PPC control methods [33]- [39] can also be avoided. 2) An ESO is adopted to estimate the unknown lumped dynamics (including frictions, parameter uncertainties, and external disturbances). The parameters of the ESO can be designed based on the bandwidth of the control system only, and thus, it is convenient to tune this parameter for practical application. 3) An improved funnel controller by combining the modified funnel variable and ESO is proposed for turntable servomechanisms with unknown lumped dynamics. This control can guarantee the transient and steady-state control error boundary. Comparative experiments are conducted based on a practical turntable servomechanisms to validate the efficacy and the improved performance of the proposed method. This paper is organized as follows. Dynamic model of servomechanisms and problem formulation are provided in Section II. Section III designs an ESO, and Section IV introduces the principle of an improved funnel function. Section V presents the funnel feedback controller and the stability analysis of the overall control system. Simulations and experiments are given in Section VI and Section VII. Some conclusions are drawn in Section VIII.

div.head: II. DYNAMIC MODEL AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: This paper will consider the turntable servomechanisms driven by a permanent magnet motor (PMSM) (Fig. 1). The model of such systems with a PMSM can be described as
div.formula: ⎛ ⎝ id iq q ⎞ ⎠ = ⎛ ⎜ ⎜ ⎜ ⎜ ⎝ -R L -n p q 0 -n p q -R L n p ψ f L 0 K T J 1 J ⎞ ⎟ ⎟ ⎟ ⎟ ⎠ i d i q q + ⎛ ⎜ ⎜ ⎜ ⎜ ⎝ u d L u q L -T f -T L -T d L ⎞ ⎟ ⎟ ⎟ ⎟ ⎠(1)
div.p: where i d and i q are the d-axis and q-axis stator currents, respectively, u d and u q are the d-axis and q-axis stator voltages, respectively, n p is the number of pole pairs, R and L are the stator resistance and stator inductance, respectively, T f , T L , and T d represent the friction torque, load torque, and disturbance torque, respectively, ψ f is the rotor flux linkage, K T is the torque constant, q and q are the angular position (rad) and velocity (rad/s), respectively, and J is the inertia (kg/m 2 ).
In practice, the d-axis reference current i * d is set to zero in order to eliminate the couplings between the angular speed and current. Thus, (1) can be written as the following form:
div.formula: iq q = ⎛ ⎜ ⎝ -R L K E L K T J 1 J ⎞ ⎟ ⎠ i q q + ⎛ ⎜ ⎝ u q L -T f -T L -T d L ⎞ ⎟ ⎠(2)
div.p: where K E = n p ψ f . For practical systems, the electrical time constant L/R is small (compared with the mechanical time constant), and thus, the transient of electrical behavior Ldi q /dt decays very rapidly to zero [45]. In this case, we choose the state vector as x = [x 1 , x 2 ] T = [q, q] T , and thus, system (1) can be simplified as
where
div.formula: K 1 = K T /R and K 2 = K T K E /R are positive constants.
div.p: The control objective is to design an appropriate feedback control u such that the rotation position x 1 tracks a given reference x d , and an ESO is designed to estimate the unknown dynamics, including frictions, parameter uncertainties, and external disturbances.
Assumption 1: The reference signals x d and ẋd are bounded, the unknown disturbance T d , nonlinear friction T f , and disturbance torque T L are all bounded.
It is noted that the derivative of the reference signal (i.e., ẋd ) will be used in the subsequent control design. This means that the proposed control is suited for continuous reference signals.

div.head: III. EXTENDED-STATE-OBSERVER DESIGN
div.p: In this paper, the nominal values of physical parameters (i.e., J , K E , K T , and R) are used in the control design. However, the parameters uncertainties, nonlinear frictions, and external disturbances (e.g., T d , T L , and T f ) will be lumped to an unknown term, which can be estimated via ESO, and then compensated in the controller design.

In order to design an ESO, we first extend the lumped unknown dynamics as an additional state variable in the system, i.e., we define x 3 = -(T d + T L + T f )/J , and thus, the system state variable x can be augmented to
Let h(t) denote the time derivative of x 3 , and then, the original system in (3) can be extended as follows:

The lumped dynamics in the servomechanism may include nonlinear frictions, parameter uncertainties, and external disturbances. These unknown dynamics will degrade the performance of the closed-loop control system. Therefore, they must be estimated and then compensated in the controller design. For this purpose, an ESO can be designed to estimate not only the state variables but also these lumped dynamics. To facilitate the design of ESO, the lumped dynamics x 3 are assumed to be with bounded derivative, i.e., h(t) is bounded. This condition is practically feasible in servo systems and thus has been widely recognized in the ESO studies (see [46] and references therein).
For the extended system (3), one may verify that it is observable, because its observability matrix [C, C A, C A 2 ] is full rank. According to [46], a linear ESO can be designed as

where x = [ x1 , x2 , x3 ] T is the observer state, and ω 0 > 0 is the gain, which denotes the bandwidth of the ESO [46]. Define the observer error as xi = x i -xi , i = 1, 2, 3. Then, from (4) and ( 5), the observer error dynamics can be given as

For ESO error (6), the transfer function between the unknown dynamics h and the observer output error x1 can be calculated as x1 / h = 1/(s 3 + 3ω 0 s 2 + 3ω 2 0 s + ω 3 0 ). Thus, the characteristic polynomial of ( 6) is
In this case, the parameter ω 0 > 0 defines the bandwidth of the observer error system, and thus should be set as a tradeoff between the observer performance and robustness [46].
To show the convergence of the adopted ESO (5), we let
, and then, ( 6) can be represented as a compact form as
div.formula: ε = ω 0 Aε + M h(t) ω 2 0 (8
div.p: where A is a Hurwitz matrix and M = [0, 0, 1] T as shown in [46]. Then, we have the following result [46]. Lemma 1: Assuming the extended variable h(t) is bounded, and then, the observer state xi is bounded, and there exists a positive constant σ i > 0 and a finite time constant T > 0 such that
Fig. 2. Funnel-control block diagram [47].
for some positive integer c. The detailed proof of Lemma 1 can be obtained following the analysis in [46], and thus will not be presented due to the limited space.

Remark 1: Based on the analysis in [46] and Lemma 1, the designed ESO is stable and the observer error can be made arbitrarily small by adjusting the bandwidth parameter ω 0 . In general, the observer performance can be improved by setting appropriately large ω 0 . However, a very large ω 0 may reduce the robustness of the proposed ESO, and cause highfrequency oscillations due to the induced high-gain integration. Thus, the parameter ω 0 should be set as a tradeoff between the observer performance and robustness.

div.head: IV. FUNNEL CONTROL AND FUNNEL VARIABLE
div.p: Funnel control, developed by Ilchmann et al. [41], is a novel control strategy which was initially developed based on stable zero dynamics, known high-frequency gain, and an adjustable proportional gain τ (•) to control systems of class S with a relative degree r = 1 or 2. The system S is governed by the funnel controller (see Fig. 2 [47]) with the control input (10) by evaluating the distance
div.formula: u(t) = τ (F ϕ (t), ψ(t), e(t) ) • e(t)
div.p: between the funnel boundary F ϕ (t) and the norm • of the error

where x d , x(t), and n(t) are the reference signal, system output, and measurement noise, respectively. The funnel boundary F ϕ (t) = 1/ϕ(t) is given by the reciprocal of an arbitrarily chosen bounded, continuous, and positive prescribed function ϕ(t) for all t ≥ 0 and lim t →∞ ϕ(t) > 0. Thus, the funnel is defined as the following set:

which encloses the error e(t) for all t ≥ 0, if the initial error e(t 0 ) is surrounded by the funnel [see Fig. 3 for illustration of a scalar error e(t)] with ϕ(t) being a scaling factor. Then, the control gain τ (•) used in conventional funnel controls [41], [47], [48] is adjusted by
div.formula: τ (F ϕ (t), ψ(t), e(t) ) = ψ(t) F ϕ (t) -e(t)(14)
div.p: Fig. 3. Basic concept of the funnel control [47].

to ensure that the error e(t) evolves inside the funnel F ϕ (t). Thus, if the error e(t) approaches the boundary F ϕ (t), the gain τ (t) will increase, and if the error e(t) is far away from the funnel boundary, the gain τ (t) will decrease.

In [48], it has been shown that an exponentially decaying funnel boundary F ϕ (t) is the most appropriate choice for linear systems with exponential transient behavior. This boundary prescribing the transient performance can be described by
where ϕ 0 , ϕ ∞ , and a are all positive constants, which should be set to fulfill the initial condition

It can be found that the parameter a determines the tracking error convergence rate, ϕ ∞ = lim t →∞ F ϕ (t) defines the ultimate allowable steadystate error bound, and ϕ 0 denotes the maximum bound of the initial tracking error (i.e., overshoot). It is worth noting that these parameters can be selected in advance by considering the above required initial conditions. However, the original funnel control [48] is limited to class S system with low relative degree (Please refer to [41] and [43] for more details on the original funnel control designs.). To relax this assumption, in this paper, we propose an improved funnel control by defining a new error variable, which is defined as

Remark 2: In ( 16), the funnel function F ϕ (t) satisfies the condition in (13), and thus, the new funnel variable ζ(t) is not necessarily limited by class S systems as imposed in standard funnel control [41], [43]. Therefore, the proposed funnel control can be widely used in practice. In the following, the funnel variable ζ(t) will be incorporated into the feedback controller design to ensure that the tracking error remains within the given funnel boundary.

div.head: V. CONTROLLER DESIGN AND STABILITY ANALYSIS
A. Controller Design
div.p: In order to guarantee the transient and steady-state tracking performance of the servomechanisms, the improved funnel variable ( 16) is incorporated into the control design. In addition, the unmatched uncertainties in (4) are estimated by using the suggested ESO. Then, a new feedback controller as shown in Fig. 4 is proposed based on a recursive design method in this section. The detailed design steps are given as follows.
Step 1: We define the position/output tracking error, z 1 , as
where x d is the desired reference. Then, from ( 16), we define the funnel error surface as
where
div.formula: F ϕ 1 (t) = ϕ 01 • exp(-a 1 t) + ϕ ∞1
div.p: is the position performance function defined in (15), whose parameter ϕ 01 is set to fulfill the initial condition
The derivative of ζ 1 with respect to time can be given by
Define the following Lyapunov function candidate as:
The time derivative of (20) becomes

In this step, x 2 is treated as a virtual control input. Then, a control variable α 2 should be designed for x 2 . Define the error variable as z 2 = x 2 -α 2 , and substitute it into (21), one can obtain the following equation:
where
Choose a virtual control law α 2 as follows:
where k 1 is a positive feedback control gain.
Step 2: In this step, the actual control law u will be obtained. The time derivative of z 2 is given by
From ( 16), we define the second funnel error as

where F ϕ 2 (t) = ϕ 02 •exp(-a 2 t)+ϕ ∞2 is the speed performance function defined in (15), whose parameter ϕ 02 is set to fulfill the initial condition |z 2 (0)| < F ϕ 2 (0). The derivative of ζ 2 with respect to time is given as
Define the following Lyapunov function candidate:
The time derivative of ( 27) is given by
In this step, the lumped dynamics x 3 are estimated by the suggested ESO, and thus, (28) can be written as
Then, the actual control law u is designed as
where k 2 is a positive constant, and

Remark 3: In ( 23) and ( 30), the feedback terms -k i ζ i , i = 1, 2 contain the newly defined funnel variable ζ i , which can be controlled to be bounded. In this case, the tracking error can be controlled fulfilling the prescribed funnel bound. This will be shown in Figs. 111213. It should be noted that the derivative of the reference signal ẋd is used in the control (23) and (30). In this respect, the proposed method is suited for tracking continuous trajectory.

Remark 4: It is noted that the PPF control proposed by Bechlioulis and Rovithakis [31], [32] can also guarantee the tracking error within a given boundary. However, the PPF control systems suffer a potential singularity problem, because the inverse transformation function of the transformed error is used. In this paper, by introducing a new funnel variable ζ(t) in ( 16), the inverse function is not needed, and thus, the singularity problem can be avoided. The proposed control is simpler and more efficient than the PPF methods since it does not need to compute the differential of the transformed error. Moreover, the imposed condition (e.g., the studied system should be the class S with low relative degree) in original funnel control [41]- [43] can be relaxed.

Remark 5: In the proposed control design, two funnel performance functions are used. The first performance function F ϕ 1 (t) is used to define the funnel variable ζ 1 of the position error z 1 in (18), while the second function F ϕ 2 (t) is used to define the funnel variable of the velocity error z 2 . Thus, different parameters ϕ 0i , ϕ ∞i , and a i may be used in these performance functions to fulfill the condition |z i (0)| < F ϕ i (0).

To implement the proposed control, all the parameters in this new control should be well tuned. In general, these parameters can be divided into two parts: the funnel parameters ϕ 0i , ϕ ∞i , and a i , which can be a priori selected to fulfill initial conditions; and the controller parameters k 1 and k 2 , which are determined based on a trial-and-error method. Here, the tuning guidelines for all parameters are given as follows.

1) Select the DOB parameter ω 0 , which depends on the bandwidth of the control system. If ω 0 is large, the observer error can be small, but the robustness of DOB may be degraded. Thus, the constant ω 0 can be set as a tradeoff between the observer performance and robustness. 2) Select the funnel parameters ϕ 0i , ϕ ∞i , and a i with respect to (15), such that the initial conditions
div.formula: |z i (0)| < F ϕi (0) hold for ϕ 0i ≥ ϕ ∞i > 0.
div.p: 3) The feedback gains k 1 and k 2 should be chosen to tradeoff the tracking precision and the smoothness of the control signals. In general, large k 1 and k 2 will lead to faster error convergence, whereas the control action may have oscillations.

div.head: B. Stability Analysis
div.p: In this section, the Lyapunov theory is employed to prove the stability and convergence of the closed-loop system.

Theorem 1: For the servomechanisms described by (3), the proposed controller ( 23), (30), and ESO (5) can guarantee that the tracking error e and the observer error x are uniformly bounded and converge to an arbitrarily small region defined by the funnel function F ϕ 1 (t).

Proof: The detailed proof can be found in the Appendix. Remark 6: From (36), Theorem 1 indicates that the proposed funnel control can guarantee the exponential convergence of funnel variables of the tracking error with convergence rate γ , and the tracking error z 1 will ultimately converge to an arbitrarily small set by choosing appropriate funnel functions.

div.head: VI. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this section, simulations are conducted to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme. The parameters of servo system (1) are given as J = 0.1 kg/m 2 , K E = 0.2 V/(rad/s), K T = 5 N • m/A, R = 5 , and T l = 0.1 N • m, and thus,
div.formula: K 1 = K T /R = 1 and K 2 = K E K T /R = 0.2,
div.p: and the unknown friction is simulated as T f = 0.007sign(x 2 ) + 0.08x 2 . Two ESOs with different bandwidths ω 0 = 60 and ω 0 = 80 are compared, and the controller parameters are chosen as k 1 = 10 and k 2 = 1. The error performance functions are set as F ϕ i (t) = ϕ 0i exp(-a i t) + ϕ ∞i with ϕ 01 = 0.08, Simulation results are shown in Figs. 5678. Figs. 5 and6 show the estimation performance of the proposed ESO with different observer bandwidths. From Figs. 5 and6, one can see that the steady-state observer errors of ESO with the bandwidth ω 0 = 80 are slightly smaller than that with the bandwidth ω 0 = 60. However, the transient observer error responses with ω 0 = 80 have more oscillations since a larger ω 0 may create a high-gain-like observer. In particular, it is shown in Fig. 6 that the unknown dynamics (e.g., T f ) can be precisely estimated by means of the adopted ESO. Moreover, the tracking control performance of the proposed funnel controller is shown in Figs. 7 and8, from where one can find that the controlled system can track the desired trajectory, and the output tracking error converges to a prescribed region that is determined by the funnel error performance functions

Remark 7: From the simulation results, it is worth noting that the selection of the observer bandwidth is essential in the design of ESO. If the observer bandwidth is too large or small, the observer performance will be degraded. Thus, we must choose appropriate observer bandwidth ω 0 such that the major work regimes can be covered by the bandwidth of the suggested ESO.

div.head: VII. EXPERIMENTAL VALIDATION
div.p: In this section, a turnable servo motor system is used to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control method.

div.head: A. Experimental Setup
div.p: The configuration of the whole experimental test-rig is shown in Fig. 9. The experimental setup consists of a permanent-magnet synchronous motor (PMSM, HC-UFS13), an encoder, and a pulsewidth modulation amplifier configured in the motor card (MR-J2S-10A). A digital signal processing board (DSP, TMS3202812) is employed as the controller with the sampling time 0.01s, and a host PC Pentium IV 2.8-GHz PC is used for display. The control algorithms are written by Visual C++ program in CCS3.0 developing environment. In the tests, the angular position of motor is measured by using an encoder with a resolution of 800 divisions, and a quadrature encoder pulse circuit is used for capturing and converting the speed and position information based on the turntable encoder. It is noted that only the yaw axis is used in our experiments.

div.head: B. Controller Design
div.p: In order to illustrate the effectiveness and the improved performance of the proposed method. The following three controllers are tested and compared in this section.

1) FCESO: This is the proposed funnel controller ( 23) and (30) with ESO (5) presented in the previous section. The controller parameters are given as k 1 = 10 and k 2 = 2, the funnel functions are described as F ϕ i (t) = ϕ 0i exp(-a i t)+ ϕ ∞i , where the parameters ϕ 01 = ϕ 02 = 0.045, ϕ ∞1 = ϕ ∞2 = 0.015, and a 1 = a 2 = 1.5. The ESO parameter is chosen as ω 0 = 65. These parameters are determined by performing a preliminary tuning procedure following the guidelines provided in Section V-A.
2) ANDSC: This is the adaptive neural dynamic surface controller (ANDSC) proposed in our previous work [49]. The errors are defined as
div.formula: z 1 = x 1 -x d and z 2 = x 2 -s 1 with μ 1 ṡ1 + s 1 = α 1 and α 1 = -k 1 z 1 -θ z 1 T 1 1 /2 -ε1 tanh(z 1 /ω 1 ), and the controller u is u = -k 2 z 2 -θ z 2 T 2 2 /2 -ε2 tanh(z 2 /ω 2 ) and adaptive laws are θi = i [z 2 i T i i -σ i θi ]/2.
div.p: The controller parameters are set as k 1 = 9, k 2 = 4, 1 = 2 = 100, μ 1 = 0.01, a1 = a2 = 10, σ 1 = σ a1 = σ a2 = 0.01, and ω 1 = ω 2 = 1. Since the same test-rig as [49] is used in this paper, the parameters of ANDSC are taken from [49], which have been well tuned.
3) PID: A PID controller is given by u
div.formula: = k p (x 1 -x d ) + k i t 0 (x 1 -x d )dt + k d d(x 1 -x d )/dt,
div.p: where the controller gains k p = 30, k i = 0.05, and k d = 25 are tuned based on a given position reference x d = 0.4 sin(2π/4) by using a trialand-error method to make a tradeoff between the steady-state performance and transient response. It should be noted that only the position feedback is used in PID control and the funnel functions are not adopted.

For fair comparisons and the ease to test the generality and robustness of above three control methods under wide operation scenarios, all control parameters are fixed in all experiments as long as they are determined based on a given reference x d = 0.4 sin(2π/4). Thus, the experiments to be presented can validate the generality of the proposed control under different operation conditions.

The following indices are adopted to compare the performance of different controls, i.e., maximal absolute error, average error, and standard deviation performance index. These indices are defined as follows: 1) the maximal absolute error I.

Case 1: The three controllers are first tested for a slowly varying sinusoid x d = 0.4 sin(2πt/4) with an amplitude of 0.4 rad and a period of 4 s. Experimental results are shown in Figs. 10 and11, which show that the tracking performance of the proposed FCESO is better than the ANDSC and PID control schemes. In particular, the tracking error of FCESO remains within the funnel boundary, while the tracking errors of the other two controllers exceed the funnel boundary. Since the employed ESO can estimate the lumped uncertainties (Fig. 10) and the error constraints are incorporated into the controller, better control performance can be obtained (Fig. 11). Specifically, compared with ANDSC, the adaptive control element and the NN approximation are all avoided. In addition, Fig. 10 also shows the estimation performance of the ESO. As it can be seen, the ESO can capture the lumped dynamics.

To further test the generality of the proposed control algorithm, sinusoidal signals with different amplitudes and periods are employed in Cases 2 and 3. The controller parameters are the same as Case 1.

Case 2: A sinusoid wave with larger amplitude and period, e.g., x d = 0.6 sin(2πt/5), is selected to verify the control performance. The tracking error is shown in Fig. 12 and the performance indices are given in Table I. It can be seen that the proposed FCESO provides better tracking performance compared with other two control methods. Moreover, FCESO ensures that the tracking error can be retained within the funnel boundary, which cannot be achieved via the other two controllers. It is noted that the funnel performance functions are not used in PID control and ANDSC scheme, so that their tracking errors may exceed the given bound. Case 3: To further compare the control performance of these three control schemes, a fast varying sinusoid x d = 0.8 sin(2π/5.5) with a larger amplitude 0.8 is used as the tracking trajectory. One can see from the experimental results in Fig. 13 that the proposed FCESO can achieve satisfactory tracking performance, where the tracking error remains within the given funnel boundary. However, the other two controllers have larger transient and steady-state tracking errors. This can also be observed from Table I, where the smallest performance indices M e , μ e , and I e are found for FCESO. These above shown experimental results illustrate the effectiveness of the suggested control approach with the funnel control constraint and ESO.

div.head: TABLE I COMPARISON RESULTS OF PERFORMANCE INDICES
div.p: The performance indices for the above three cases are summarized in Table I. From Table I, one can see that the proposed FCESO gives smaller M e , μ e , and I e than other two control methods in all cases. The ANDSC can achieve a comparable control performance in terms of steadystate performance indices (e.g., μ e ); however, the transient tracking error of ANDSC exceeds the funnel boundary. Nevertheless, the control performance of ANDSC is much better than PID. Specifically, PID control and ANDSC scheme lead to significant oscillations in the error responses since the fixed PID parameters and adaptation algorithm are used, respectively, which may be sensitive to highfrequency noise. However, this can be remedied in this paper, because the unknown dynamics can be estimated and compensated in terms of ESO. All the aforementioned experiment results clearly show that the proposed ESO-based funnel control scheme can ensure a fairly good prescribed control performance.

To test the validity of the adopted ESO, we manually add a disturbance d = -2x 1 as the input disturbance to the servo motor. In this case, the estimated dynamics from ESO should include both the internal uncertainties (e.g., friction) and the added disturbance. The estimated responses of ESO and the corresponding control error profiles are shown in Fig. 14, where both the cases with and without external disturbance are tested. Fig. 14(a) shows the control and estimation responses without d = -2x 1 . In this case, the estimated internal dynamics are shown in the second subplot in Fig. 14(a). Then, it can be found from Fig. 14(b) that this artificial disturbance d = -2x 1 can be estimated in terms of the ESO, and thus, the corresponding tracking error can be retained within the given funnel bounds.

Finally, we use a saw tooth signal with sudden jumps to show the ability and applicability of the proposed control. The funnel parameters are chosen as F ϕ i (t) = ϕ 0i exp(-a i t) + ϕ ∞i , where the parameters ϕ 01 = ϕ 02 = 0.25, ϕ ∞1 = ϕ ∞2 = 0.05, and a 1 = a 2 = 1.5. Similar to the previous study, an artificial disturbance d = -2x 1 is added into the system as the input disturbance. The observer performance of ESO and tracking performance with and without disturbance are shown in Fig. 15(a) and (b), respectively. One may find that the ESO can accurately estimate the lumped uncertainties in this system, and thus, the satisfactory tracking performance can also be achieved for such references with jumps.

div.head: VIII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, an improved funnel feedback controller based on ESO has been proposed for servomechanisms to retain both the transient and steady-state error within the prescribed funnel boundary. A modified funnel function characterizing the transient boundary and asymptotic convergence is incorporated into the control design. The complex transformation and the potential singularity in the PPC methods are all avoided. Moreover, the strict assumption on the system that was imposed in conventional funnel control schemes is also relaxed. On the other hand, the friction dynamics and the external disturbances are all considered by using the ESO. In this case, only one parameter of ESO (e.g., the bandwidth) needs to be selected. This would lead to simpler implementation and decreased computational costs. The closed-loop system stability and the convergence of the tracking error within the funnel boundary are all rigorously proved through the Lyapunov theory. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated by simulations and practical experiments based on a turntable servo system.

From (36) and Lemma 1, one can conclude that the signals z 1 , z 2 , and ε are all bounded, which means that the state x and the estimation x are bounded. In this case, following a similar analysis, we can further get |z 1 | ≤ μ. Therefore, the output tracking error z 1 = x 1x d can be retained within the prescribed funnel bound determined by F ϕ1 (t). This completes the proof.

div.p: This paper was recommended for publication by Associate Editor Y. Zhang and Editor D. Tilbury upon evaluation of the reviewers' comments. This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61433003, Grant 61273150, Grant 61573174, and Grant 61321002.
His current research interests include motor drive control and integration of mechanism parameters and controller design.
